intro: Quercus sessiliflora var. platyphylla, commonly known as the Mexican white oak, is a deciduous tree native to the southern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Fagaceae family and is characterized by its broad, lobed leaves that are typically 10–20 cm in length. The tree produces small, cupule-enclosed acorns that mature over a period of several months. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in dry, open woodlands. Its botanical features make it an important species for ecological studies and conservation efforts in its native range.
